awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Mechanisms for Mechanochemical Behaviors of Glass Surfaces - An Integrated Experimental and Computational Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: 
The strength and wear resistance of glass are important properties for many consumer products including mobile phones, displays, automotive/aerospace windows, and for the safety of glass, in general. Although several strengthening processes such as tempering and ion-exchange are currently used in industry, the scientific foundations are not all fully understood. This limits further improvements in glass strength and reliability. The strength of glass is controlled by surface damage created in manufacturing and handling, as well as by the composition of the glass. This project engages in research to better understand the combined effects of mechanical stress and surface chemistry (called mechanochemistry). The scientific findings of this research are directly beneficial to glass manufacturers as well as users of glass in product development.
 
TECHNICAL DETAILS: 
Mechanical and mechanochemical properties of silicate glass surfaces in ambient air are sensitive to alkali ion leaching and its exchange with hydrous species (hydroxyl or water). This research hypothesizes that interfacial shear or mechanical deformation causes local distortion of the silicate network surrounding the hydrous species such that the distance between the bridging oxygen of the Si-O-Si network and the hydrous species becomes shorter than the critical length needed to induce hydrolysis of the Si-O-Si network. This hypothesis is relevant to several important questions that are outstanding in glass science such as stress-induced transport of sodium ions and the catalytic effects of metal ions on hydrolysis of glass network. While existing stress corrosion theory can explain crack growth under an applied tensile stress, it cannot fully explain the chemical reactivity of confined water in contact with glass under both compressive and shear stress. This project employs density functional theory (DFT) and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with reactive force fields (ReaxFF) to study the key hypothesis and related questions, and theoretical calculation results are tested and validated experimentally using state-of-the-art surface analysis techniques. This project educates undergraduate and graduate students in the engineering and science of materials with a focus on glass and its strength. The research team recruits students from underrepresented groups to work on the project. All students benefit from participation activities associated with various interdisciplinary materials research activities at the Materials Research Institute (MRI) and Material Computation Center (MCC) at Penn State. The team offers computational data to the Nanohub and the Knowledgebase of Interatomic Models (OpenKim) websites, so that their user-base can access these materials for future force field development and validation projects. Selected examples of the ReaxFF and DFT simulations and surface analysis results are integrated in two existing graduate courses.

por.por_cntn:
This project deepened fundamental understanding of the mechanochemical property of silicate glass surfaces in humid environments. Glass is an intricate amorphous network between network formers (Si, Al, etc.) and network modifiers (alkali, alkaline earth, etc.). Although the interplay between these two were believed to determine the intrinsic strength of glass, it is well documented that the practical strength of glass is greatly affected by environmental conditions, especially humidity. Thus, it is very important to understand how the surface properties of silicate glass are affected and altered by the humidity (more accurately, water molecules impinging from the gas phase). While existing stress corrosion theory can explain crack growth under an applied tensile stress, it cannot fully explain the chemical reactivity of glass surfaces in the presence of adsorbed water molecules under both compressive and shear stress. The key scientific question studied here was how interfacial water molecules react with network formers and modifier ions under mechanical shear conditions.

 

Intellectual merit: This question was investigated using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations with reactive force fields (ReaxFF), and theoretical calculation results were tested and validated experimentally using state-of-the-art surface analysis techniques. The team developed a ReaxFF force field for sodium that is compatible with Si/O/H fields, allowing MD simulations of chemical reactions of sodium silicate with water. Using this force field, the team elucidated chemical reactions activated by mechanical shear at the silicate glass surface and how the presence of interfacial water molecules alters reaction pathways as well as wear and sub-surface damage of the surface. Another major milestone was to find the empirical correlation between the Si-O stretch vibration mode of the silica and silicate glass network and the Si-O bond length distribution. By combining the ReaxFF simulations and vibrational spectroscopy, it was confirmed that after frictional contact with a foreign object, there are subsurface residual strains in the Si-O bond length in the contacted region. When this surface was exposed to base solution, the contacted region with subsurface deformation was found to be more susceptible to hydrolysis. This proved that hydrolysis reactions of the glass network are facilitated if the bond length distribution of the glass network is distorted deviating from the most relaxed structure, which was the key hypothesis proposed at the beginning of the project. By using ReaxFF simulations, we also have shown that the porous layer, formed on soda lime glass by leaching of sodium modifier ions, undergoes mechanochemical restructuring under the indentation pressure. This phenomenon slowed down the water transport through the leached layer to the sub-surface crack tip, making the leached glass more resistant to cracking opening.

 

Broader impacts: Four students worked in this project are now working in glass industries. Dr. Jiawei Luo is now working at OFS Optics, a world-leading manufacturer of optical fibers. Dr. Nisha Sheth is working in a glass and glass-ceramic division at Apple. Dr. Seung Ho Hahn is at Samsung Electronics. Dr. Hongshen Liu will join Corning Inc. this summer. Many undergraduate students were also involved in this project and three of them are now pursuing PhD degrees in materials science. All these students had non-travel based cultural experiences by collaborating with Dr. Hongtu He, a visiting scientist from China. The Si/O/H/Na force field is widely being used by other glass research scientists. The team also worked with a small non-profit organization to investigate why certain thermally-tempered glasses are more susceptible to scratch during typical window cleaning process. The team also helped a researcher at AGC Flat Glass North America to understand the environmental effect on adhesion of tin oxide coating on soda lime solar cell panel.
